schools played ns good personality habits such honesty
and fair play James Dugan first lose

Views, pRevIewS
AND REVIEWS


Edward Ranks

Lott Cary semade Negro preacher started out in
life as Of the world but 1907 he hearing


forceful Not long thereafter exorer in
the African Baptist Church In Richmond Virginia congre
cation consisted Of about 1000 members had employ
assistant pastors.


The turning point in Lott Cars life hearing
Christian work foreign fields made by Luther Rice
missionary This led the organization that year Richmond
Foreign Missionary Society," which cooperated Baptist
Trennial Convention Later followed from this plan
ganzaton Of the Richmond African Baptist Missionary Society
Lott Cary the moving spirit Members only
from the African Baptist Church but from others of the city,
body held annual meetings and during years
lated $500.


When the time commission IN the
African field which these funds would support
eered CO. accompanied by Collin league They duly
pointed by the Baptist Trieal Convention missionaries
Liberia. They sailed with others Norfolk January


In LIBERIA Lott Cary took his energy
He established churches and preached continuously He
need for other efforts however, and he devoted
education as he did religion Being of striking person
atty too Cary welcomed leader in whatever he chose
to He showed himself be such successful admins
traitor in the various positions in which he had served that
American Colonization Society made him vce-agen Of the whole
colony One Of his first duties in this position protect the
homes Of the civilized people from crude natives who UNDER
standing the meaning this settlement tried destroy While
making preparations against their raids Carywas accidentally


killed by explosion in the ammunition
of

the public market are entirely
lost--but shop you must. On this
Saturday as wheeled my wobbly
cart to the checkout line a mere
slip Of boy looked up at me
and said, IL don't like you'll"


Had he said that at any other
time ! might have replied sharp
err. But this Saturday had just
about drained me. ! had exhaust
ed myself cleaning, driving and
shopping - l was hungry and
weary.


When told the little chap |
really didn't care, but | thought
| liked him--he stopped and gave
me a stare. Then he began to
climb onto my cart.

His mother looked bit dazed
and edgy. Alphabetically, she
tried to halt fist fight develop
ing between her other two young
sters. thought Of an old saying
that some days 1t pays to stay in
bed.


To top off the Saturday to end
all Saturdays--on the way home
from the supermarket a nervous
motorist bumped my car forward.
Evidently ! wasn't moving up
fast enough to suit him. alight-
ed from my car and told him to
have a bit more patience or he
could fly over. Muttering a few
curses he glowered and probably
went home grouching about a
black Saturday. too.

depending on your natal day..
Saturday Is special day. Satur-
day Is either one of pain or
pleasure. There Is no halfway
point for Saturday.


When you are young Saturday
is perhaps the most wonderful
day of the week. All pupils look
forward to the day as one Of
blessed release from less ons and
the teachers.


Can you recall any great high
lights of your Hfe7 I'll wager a
greenback or two--that some
thing either wonderful or horrible
happened on a Saturday.


Saturdays we're full of mean
ing for me when l was growing
up in Indianapolis, Indiana. Sat-
urday meant going to the library.
Saturday meant going to the pub
lie market. Saturday meant
cleaning house. Saturday meant
my grandparents, either mater
nal or paternal. depending on
where was staying at the time.


My group of childhood friends
congregated on Saturdays at my
Mother house They came bright
and early If we we're going to
town or to just hang around. In
the summer we would have our
bikes ready for an early morning
ride, If 1t we're winter we would
be ready for a SNOWFALL fight or
a sled ride.


Some Saturdays | would have
been the first person up and out
on our street. Fresh, white snow
was a lure couldn't resist.
I would go to sleep on Friday
night (while 1t was snoMng) with
one thought in mind-to be the first
one out in the snow on our
street. I am sure modern psy-
chiatrists could attach some hid
den meaning to this desire. Maybe
they never stepped in the glist-
ening. blanket Of white crystals
and heard 1t crunch underfoot.


Saturdays we're housekeeping
days. l liked to arise early with
my grandfather Racker and start
working. He was good company
for me, but not housecleaner.
My Grandfather Waterman be-
LEVIED homework was strictly
woman's duty. never saw him
mop, sweep, cook a meal (unless
you considered a cup of coffee
and a grease fried egg as meal).


Twice year was wallpaper
cleaning time. | can't remember
the millions Of strokes ! must
have made in our house Mping
those CRIME covered walls in May
and November. That wallpaper
cleaner had the strangest odor--
like kerosene and gum combined.


Saturdays we're market days.
Our day was not complete without
at least one trip to the public
market. You could go early in
the morning to get the fresh
vegetables and fruit, or you could
go late just before closing time
and catch some bargains. Look
Ing backward. | think loved to
go to the market just to buy a
Kosher sandwich and watch the
sellers bark the prices Of the
wares.


The market was a city within
a city. Housed in an old con-
crete and wooden structure. The
outside entrances housed flow
ers. potted plants. (none of these
artificials of today. Meat coun-
tiers piled high with whole chick
ems, red beefsteaks, rosy pork
roast and assorted lamb, veal and
rabbit meat welcomed the buyers.


Saturday, January seventh. was
a usual day. cleaned the house

Somewhere, the modern education and
recreation programs haze gone 0stYay.
Somehow, modern theories and family or
g0nlz0tiOn studies haze UeeYed. Soneuuv.
modern principles for chih-Yeayi,zg and youth
development haze be come tangled. Youth crime
rates in Phoenix and AzQ11coba County are
alarming.


ACCORDING to recent REPORT by Police
Chief Paul Bhbauna, juvenile crime in the
CITY has increased I 500 cases since the
last years. report, When Il, $50 comp laints
WeTe tsIed against persons under Is.
lhss IS shocking figure and many more
cases neUeT are counted be cause citizens
are reluctant to report certain juveniles.
juveniles haze been kno1Om TO threaten both
children and ADULTS If their crimes are made
kpoama to the police.


What kind Of a Civilization are ne bYOduc-
ing What kind Of generations Of the future
WiH eOOlUe from the ulde number Of young
persons aOho openly flaaat LAM and order?
Numerous homes are broken into d4yipzg
daylight hours and the young culbYits often
return to the same houses within a month.
Schools are tauoYite hau,ats Of youthful
criminals. They destroy thousands Of dol
lars worth Of materials annually. They are
usually knoaOn offenders, Uho laugh waen
0bbYehended.


We can not expect LAM agencies to take
care of the rising juvenile crime rates
alone. 1t IS time for rs to place YeSbon-
Sibihty for juvenile acts with their par
entS. Perhaps, it isn't too late for the
home to be the primary source of guiding
children TOWARD Yesbe citing LAM and order.
